message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is the most useful in detecting recurrence and monitoring treatment in colon cancer patients. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is used to detect liver cancer or testicular cancer. CA-125 is used in ovarian cancer, and gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) is used as a marker for liver or pancreas disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a tumor marker commonly used to monitor for reoccurrence in colorectal cancer patients, making it the correct answer. Alpha-fetoprotein is more commonly monitored in liver cancer, while CA-125 is more commonly monitored in ovarian cancer. Gamma glutamyl transferase is a liver enzyme that may be elevated in certain liver diseases, but is not a specific marker for cancer recurrence.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a tumor marker commonly used to monitor for recurrence of colon cancer. Alpha-fetoprotein is used in liver cancer, CA-125 is used in ovarian cancer, and Gamma glutamyl transferase is a liver enzyme used in liver function tests, but none of these are specific for colon cancer recurrence.

Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a tumor marker commonly used to monitor patients who have had colon cancer surgery, as elevated levels can indicate recurrence. Alpha-fetoprotein is used to monitor liver cancer, CA-125 is used to monitor ovarian cancer, and gamma glutamyl transferase is a marker for liver disease but not specific to cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a tumor marker that is elevated in many types of cancer, including colorectal cancer. Therefore, it is used to monitor for cancer recurrence in patients who have had colorectal cancer resection. Alpha-fetoprotein is a tumor marker that is elevated in liver cancer, germ cell tumors, and some other cancers. CA-125 is a tumor marker that is elevated in ovarian cancer and some other cancers. Gamma glutamyl transferase is an enzyme that is elevated in liver disease and alcohol abuse, but not specifically in cancer.

Alpha-fetoprotein is used as a marker for liver cancer and germ cell tumors, CA-125 is used to monitor ovarian cancer, and gamma glutamyl transferase is a liver enzyme that can be elevated in a variety of liver and biliary diseases.

Alpha-fetoprotein is elevated in liver cancer, CA-125 is elevated in ovarian cancer, and Gamma glutamyl transferase is elevated in liver and biliary tract diseases.

Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is commonly used as a tumor marker for colorectal cancer, and its levels can be monitored to check for cancer recurrence in this patient. Alpha-fetoprotein is used as a tumor marker for liver and testicular cancer, CA-125 for ovarian cancer, and gamma glutamyl transferase for liver disease.
